p:
A random effects model was built to account for additional between-study variability beyond sampling error [ 29]. The true effects of sample studies are assumed to be composed of some unknown average true population effect size μ along with normally distributed deviation u
i ∼ N(0, τ 2), i.e., θ
i = μ + u
i . Eq (2) then becomes
y i
= μ +
u i
+
e i
.
(6) The average true effect μ was estimated and restricted maximum-likelihood estimation (REML) was used to estimate the total amount of heterogeneity among the true effects τ 2. The I 2 statistic, which estimates what percent of the total variability in effect size estimates is due to heterogeneity among the true effects, is reported in the results.
